awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides renewed funding for the participation of junior faculty in the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER) Summer Institute. For more than thirty years, NBER's Summer Institute has offered an ideal environment for developing new ideas and forging collaborative work relationships. Summer Institute brings together economists and scholars in other fields from universities, government, and international organizations for a few days or a few weeks of seminars, workshops, conferences, and cooperative research. The NBER Summer Institutes generate timely and influential research on important economic policy questions related to such topics as international financial stability, economic productivity and technology, environmental regulations, social security policy, and educational policies. The workshops are an invaluable part of the research infrastructure in economics and assist the research of many economists. 


The Summer Institute is four weeks long and includes at least 50 sessions organized and co-organized by over 100 individuals. There are more than 2,800 attendees each summer from over 425 universities and non-academic institutions. About two-thirds of all attendees are not NBER affiliates. While there are many presentations of work nearing completion, emphasis is placed on the workshop aspects of the program where new ideas are raised, preliminary research ideas are developed, and plans for joint or coordinated research efforts are established. Efforts are made to include a wide variety of new participants, and to reach out to women and minorities. Calls for papers are circulated widely and are available on the NBER website.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the NBER's Summer Institute meetings for four consecutive years, 2019-2022.  These three-week meetings brought together applied economists in a wide range of different fields to share their latest research findings, attend lectures, and plan for their future research projects.  The 2019 NBER Summer Institute attracted 2,875 registered participants from 474 universities and non-academic institutions.  The 2020 NBER Summer Institute, which was held in a virtual format because of the COVID-19 pandemic, attracted 3,800 participants from 556 universities and non-academic institutions.  The 2021 NBER Summer Institute, also held virtually, attracted 4,340 participants from 646 universities and non-academic institutions.  The 2022 NBER Summer Institute was held in a hybrid format and attracted 3,579 participants, 2,299 in person, from 525 universities and non-academic institutions.  About two thirds of the participants in these meetings were not NBER affiliates, and roughly one fifth were first-time Summer Institute participants.

 

Each Summer Institute included roughly fifty distinct research meetings, each focused on a distinct sub-field within economics.  The number of research papers presented at the Summer Institute varied between 547 and 639.  A complete list of the sessions for 2019 through 2022 meetings can be found at:

 

https://www.nber.org/conferences/summer-institute

 

Each of the Summer Institute meetings included a mini-course titled the “Methods Lectures” The topic varied from year to year.  In 2019, the topic was “Research Transparency and Reproducibility” and the lectures were given by Edward Miguel of the University of California, Berkeley.  In 2020 the topic was “Differential Privacy for Economists” and the lecturers were Daniel Goroff of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, Daniel Kifer of Pennsylvania State University, Ian Schmutte of the University of Georgia, and Frauke Kreuter of the University of Maryland.  In 2021, the topic was “Causal Inference Using Synthetic Controls and Regression Discontinuity Designs” and the lecturers were Alberto Abadie of MIT, and Matias Cattaneo and Rocio Titiunik, both of Princeton University.  In 2022, the lectures focused on “Empirical Bayes Methods, Theory and Application.”  They were presented by Jiaying Gu of the University of Toronto and Christopher R. Walters of the University of California, Berkeley.  When the Summer Institute meetings were in person, the lectures attracted a substantial in-person audience comprised primarily of junior scholars and graduate students.  The key audience for these lectures, however, has been on-line; the four sets of “Methods Lectures” between 2019 and 2022 have attracted more than 23,000 views on the NBER YouTube channel.  All of the lectures are posted on the NBER website as well:

 

https://www.nber.org/research/lectures

 

Each of the Summer Institute meetings also include a Martin Feldstein Lecture, a lecture that honors the contributions of the NBER’s longest-serving president.  The 2019 lecture was presented by Katherine Baicker of the University of Chicago, speaking on “Economic Analysis for Evidence-Based Policy in Health Care: Progress and Pitfalls.” The 2020 lecture was presented by Claudia Goldin of Harvard University. Her lecture was titled “Journey across a Century of Women.” The 2021 lecture, by Alan Auerbach of the University of California, Berkeley, was “The Taxation of Business Income in the Global Economy.” The 2022 lecture was presented by Gita Gopinath of the International Monetary Fund. She spoke on “Managing a Turn in the Global Financial Cycle.”  When the Summer Institute meetings were in person, the Feldstein Lectures were attended by about 250 participants.  The text of each lecture was published in the NBER Reporter. Videos of these lectures are available on the NBER web site at:

 

https://www.nber.org/feldstein_lectures.html

 

After a call for nominations, more than 100 late-stage graduate students were invited to participate in each of the four Summer Institutes between 2019 and 2022.  In addition, the NBER has an initiative to invite some of the most promising graduates of the AEA’s Summer Training Program to participate.  Many of these students are from minority groups that are under-represented in the economics profession. 

 

Beginning with the virtual Summer Institute in 2020, video of most Summer Institute sessions was posted on the NBER YouTube channel for several days after the meeting.  These videos have proven very popular: the NBER had less than 25 YouTube subscribers before the 2020 Summer Institute.  That number rose to over 16,000 in the subsequent four years.  Many recordings attract more than 500 views.  The availability of these recordings has been an important way of expanding access to the research presentations at the NBER Summer Institute. 

 


Last Modified: 05/22/2024
Modified by: James M Poterba
por.por_txt_cntn:
This project supported the NBER's Summer Institute meetings for four consecutive years, 2019-2022. These three-week meetings brought together applied economists in a wide range of different fields to share their latest research findings, attend lectures, and plan for their future research projects. The 2019 NBER Summer Institute attracted 2,875 registered participants from 474 universities and non-academic institutions. The 2020 NBER Summer Institute, which was held in a virtual format because of the COVID-19 pandemic, attracted 3,800 participants from 556 universities and non-academic institutions. The 2021 NBER Summer Institute, also held virtually, attracted 4,340 participants from 646 universities and non-academic institutions. The 2022 NBER Summer Institute was held in a hybrid format and attracted 3,579 participants, 2,299 in person, from 525 universities and non-academic institutions. About two thirds of the participants in these meetings were not NBER affiliates, and roughly one fifth were first-time Summer Institute participants.





Each Summer Institute included roughly fifty distinct research meetings, each focused on a distinct sub-field within economics. The number of research papers presented at the Summer Institute varied between 547 and 639. A complete list of the sessions for 2019 through 2022 meetings can be found at:





https://www.nber.org/conferences/summer-institute





Each of the Summer Institute meetings included a mini-course titled the Methods Lectures The topic varied from year to year. In 2019, the topic was Research Transparency and Reproducibility and the lectures were given by Edward Miguel of the University of California, Berkeley. In 2020 the topic was Differential Privacy for Economists and the lecturers were Daniel Goroff of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, Daniel Kifer of Pennsylvania State University, Ian Schmutte of the University of Georgia, and Frauke Kreuter of the University of Maryland. In 2021, the topic was Causal Inference Using Synthetic Controls and Regression Discontinuity Designs and the lecturers were Alberto Abadie of MIT, and Matias Cattaneo and Rocio Titiunik, both of Princeton University. In 2022, the lectures focused on Empirical Bayes Methods, Theory and Application. They were presented by Jiaying Gu of the University of Toronto and Christopher R. Walters of the University of California, Berkeley. When the Summer Institute meetings were in person, the lectures attracted a substantial in-person audience comprised primarily of junior scholars and graduate students. The key audience for these lectures, however, has been on-line; the four sets of Methods Lectures between 2019 and 2022 have attracted more than 23,000 views on the NBER YouTube channel. All of the lectures are posted on the NBER website as well:





https://www.nber.org/research/lectures





Each of the Summer Institute meetings also include a Martin Feldstein Lecture, a lecture that honors the contributions of the NBERs longest-serving president. The 2019 lecture was presented by Katherine Baicker of the University of Chicago, speaking on Economic Analysis for Evidence-Based Policy in Health Care: Progress and Pitfalls. The 2020 lecture was presented by Claudia Goldin of Harvard University. Her lecture was titled Journey across a Century of Women. The 2021 lecture, by Alan Auerbach of the University of California, Berkeley, was The Taxation of Business Income in the Global Economy. The 2022 lecture was presented by Gita Gopinath of the International Monetary Fund. She spoke on Managing a Turn in the Global Financial Cycle. When the Summer Institute meetings were in person, the Feldstein Lectures were attended by about 250 participants. The text of each lecture was published in the NBER Reporter. Videos of these lectures are available on the NBER web site at:





https://www.nber.org/feldstein_lectures.html





After a call for nominations, more than 100 late-stage graduate students were invited to participate in each of the four Summer Institutes between 2019 and 2022. In addition, the NBER has an initiative to invite some of the most promising graduates of the AEAs Summer Training Program to participate. Many of these students are from minority groups that are under-represented in the economics profession.





Beginning with the virtual Summer Institute in 2020, video of most Summer Institute sessions was posted on the NBER YouTube channel for several days after the meeting. These videos have proven very popular: the NBER had less than 25 YouTube subscribers before the 2020 Summer Institute. That number rose to over 16,000 in the subsequent four years. Many recordings attract more than 500 views. The availability of these recordings has been an important way of expanding access to the research presentations at the NBER Summer Institute.
